questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Habakkuk 1:1-11 aloud, focusing on the repeated cry for help and the shock of God's response.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'how long' (v. 2) expressing frustration
Pay attention to the contrast between Habakkuk's complaint (v. 2-3) and God's answer (v. 5-11)
The phrase 'I am doing a work in your days that you would not believe' (v. 5) is a key emotional pivot

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize who (Habakkuk) is complaining to, what (the injustice and God's silence), where (in Judah), why (the wicked prospering while the righteous suffer).
tips: Habakkuk's complaint about God's inaction (v. 2-3)
The revelation of the Chaldeans as God's instrument (v. 5-10)
The contrast between God's holiness and the wickedness of the world (v. 11)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Habakkuk's cry for help (v. 2), the Chaldeans being raised up (v. 5-6), or God's declaration of His holiness (v. 11)?
tips: The phrase 'I am doing a work in your days that you would not believe' (v. 5) is shocking because it reveals God's use of a violent force (the Chaldeans) that Judah would not understand
The description of the Chaldeans: 'horses are swifter than leopards' (v. 6) creates a vivid image of their terrifying power
God's response in v. 11: 'I am holy, I am pure, I am the one who sees the wicked' - this emphasizes God's unchanging holiness despite human sin

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Habakkuk trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Habakkuk is calling Judah to recognize that God's justice, though delayed, will ultimately prevail through a seemingly violent and unexpected agent (the Chaldeans).
This passage shows that God's sovereignty is not to be confused with indifference to sin; He is actively working even when the righteous suffer.
The main point is that God's judgment on sin is inevitable and will come through a force that Judah cannot comprehend, but He remains holy and just.

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The Chaldeans as God's instrument, the concept of God's silence, and the meaning of 'purifier of eyes'.
tips: The Chaldeans (Babylon) were a foreign power that Habakkuk's people (Judah) had not encountered before; this shows God's use of unexpected agents for judgment.
Habakkuk's complaint about God's silence (v. 2) is a common human experience, but God's response is that He is working in a way that Judah cannot comprehend.
The phrase 'the Holy One of purer eyes than to see evil' (v. 13) refers to God's absolute holiness and inability to be corrupted by sin, which contrasts with the wickedness of the world.

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Habakkuk's cry for help reminds us that we may feel God is silent. What situation requires you to trust God's timing and provision this week?
tips: When you feel God is not responding to your prayers, ask: 'Is there a way He is working in a way I don't see?'
Consider an area where you are holding back from trusting God's plan (like a relationship or financial situation).
Practice 'waiting in faith' by focusing on God's character (v. 13) rather than the immediate results.

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about God's justice and the unexpected means He uses.
tips: Thank God that He sees the wickedness and will bring judgment without being swayed by human opinion.
Ask for the courage to trust God's timing even when it feels like He is silent.
Pray for the Holy Spirit to help you see God's work in the world, especially in the Chaldean (Babylonian) empire.

chapters.chapterTitle: The Righteous Shall Live by Faith

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Habakkuk 2:1-19 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the prophet's distress and God's assurance.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the vision' (v.2, v.3)
Pay attention to the phrase 'the righteous shall live by faith' (v.4)
The emotional shift from the prophet's waiting (v.1) to God's promise (v.4)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize WHO is involved (Habakkuk and God), WHAT God is doing (answering the prophet's vision), WHERE this happens (in the context of the watchpost), and WHY the prophet is waiting (for God's timing).
tips: Habakkuk's initial complaint about God's delay (v.1)
God's command to write the vision (v.2-3)
The promise that the righteous live by faith (v.4)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the vision awaiting its appointed time (v.3), the declaration that the righteous live by faith (v.4), or the earth being filled with God's glory (v.14).
tips: The phrase 'the vision awaits its appointed time' (v.3) shows God's patience and faithfulness
The declaration 'the righteous shall live by faith' (v.4) is a cornerstone of Christian theology
The image of 'the earth filled with the knowledge of the glory of the LORD' (v.14) points to the future kingdom of God

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Habakkuk trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Habakkuk warns Judah about their sin and the need for faith in God's promises rather than their own efforts
The message is that God's timing is certain (the vision will come) and the righteous will live by faith (not by works)
This passage addresses the current state of Judah (wickedness) and points to the coming glory of God

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of the vision awaiting time, the definition of 'righteous living by faith', and the description of the wicked in verses 5-11.
tips: The phrase 'the vision awaits its appointed time' (v.3) means God has a specific time for the fulfillment of His promises, not that He is slow to act
In the context of Habakkuk 2, 'the righteous shall live by faith' means that true righteousness comes through trust in God's promises (not human effort) and is a response to God's faithfulness
The description of the wicked (wine, greed, blood) shows the consequences of sin in the context of Judah's society

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you live by faith in the midst of current challenges (like the wickedness in the world) this week?
tips: Identify a situation where you are relying on your own efforts rather than trusting God's promises
Practice waiting on God's timing (like Habakkuk) in your daily life
Share the truth that 'the righteous shall live by faith' with someone who is struggling

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the promise that the righteous live by faith. Ask for the strength to trust Him in difficult circumstances.
tips: Thank God for the promise that the righteous live by faith (v.4)
Pray for the courage to trust God when facing trials (like the wickedness in the world)
Ask God to help you live by faith in the midst of the current challenges

Pause if something strikes you
